author: 0xraino
content:
<@!364458974906548225> <@!682078300234973185> 

This is based off shaky memory from the last stateless call.

I believe people were ok with doing regenesis with the hexary trie _if_ our empirical investigations into hexary witnesses show us it's alright and for some reason we couldn't get the binary conversion done before.

I remember a take away from <@!682078300234973185> based on something I said was that we wanted the same trie structure before and after regenesis so the proofs would work. I realized I must've been mistaken because we just need to keep the last pre-regenesis block's hexary state root hash to prove the leaves which can then just be inserted into a post-regenesis binary trie.

_If_ our empirical investigations into hexary witnesses for regenesis show us that it's alright, then we should be good to switch the trie format over along with regenesis right?

author: pipermerriam
content: Yes, there is nothing I am aware of that strictly restricts us from having hexary before regenesis and binary after.

author: pipermerriam
content: But clients will still have to determine what the new binary trie state root should be so this doesn't eliminate the need for some kind of hexary->binary migration within the protocol.

author: pipermerriam
content: Also, binary trie transition is a *big* thing, and regenesis is a *big* thing and we probably shouldn't try to do them at the same time.....

author: 0xraino
content: That's totally fair, just wanted to walk back what I thought about them _needing_ to happen in a certain order

author: pipermerriam
content: And since we know binary trie reduces proof sizes in a significant way, and that regenesis is going to introduce proofs into the core protocol, it seems like the natural order is to do the trie conversion first, then regenesis.....   but I'm happy to debate this

author: pipermerriam
content: No strict requirement that I'm aware of on the ordering of the two things
